item.title: Neighbors Say Suspect in French Attacks and His Companion Lived Quiet Lives
item.description: When the French police raided the home of Amedy Coulibaly, a suspected Islamic extremist, in May 2010, they found 340 gun cartridges for a Kalashnikov automatic rifle.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Uncredited/Prefecture de Police Paris, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Amedy Coulibaly, left, and Hayat Boumeddiene.

item.title: World Briefing: Lebanon: Bombing Kills at Least 7 People at a Cafe
item.description: A suicide bombing at a coffee shop in the northern city of Tripoli killed at least seven people and wounded more than 30 on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Libya: Rival Factions Agree to Negotiations, U.N. Says
item.description: Libya’s factions have agreed to a new round of negotiations backed by the United Nations to try to end the conflict that is destabilizing the country after its civil war in 2011.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Cambodia: 212 H.I.V. Cases Linked to Contamination
item.description: The infected villagers were found in a district where an unlicensed medic has been accused of spreading the virus with contaminated equipment, according to findings released by the government.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Police Defuse Bomb Found at an Istanbul Mall
item.description: The police defused an improvised bomb found in a mall in an eastern suburb of Istanbul on Saturday, Turkey’s private Dogan news agency said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Jihadists and Supporters Take to Social Media to Praise Attack on Charlie Hebdo
item.description: For jihadists from North Africa to Pakistan, the attack in Paris was a justified blow against a country perceived as an enemy of Islam.
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Bureh Beach Journal: No Moon Suits, Just Trunks and the Healing Surf
item.description: As Ebola gnaws through Sierra Leone, those at Bureh Beach Surf Club teach and feed tourists, eking out a living seemingly determined to pursue their passion as a way to cope.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a Sierra Leone plagued by Ebola, Bureh Beach Surf Club members find resilience in a passion.

item.title: Open Source: Muslim Employee of Kosher Market in Paris Praised for Hiding Customers From Gunman
item.description: A Muslim employee, credited with saving the lives of customers at a kosher market in Paris on Friday, was praised online for his efforts.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Iran and Venezuela Push OPEC to Stabilize Falling Oil Prices
item.description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela and President Hassan Rouhani of Iran want OPEC members to cut production to increase prices as the cost of oil has plunged to less than $50 a barrel.
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: News Analysis: New Courts Offer Pakistan’s Generals the Power They Used to Seize
item.description: The government of Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif is hanging on, extending a nearly seven-year stretch of nominal civilian rule, but otherwise, the military is back in the driver’s seat.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: An officer stood guard outside Parliament in Islamabad as legislators voted to amend the Constitution to allow military courts.

item.title: French Premier Declares ‘War’ on Radical Islam as Paris Girds for Rally
item.description: Law enforcement officials appealed to the public to help find Hayat Boumeddiene, the girlfriend of Amedy Coulibaly, who took hostages at a kosher supermarket.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: In Nigeria, New Boko Haram Suicide Bomber Tactic: ‘It’s a Little Girl’
item.description: Witnesses said a bomb carried by a girl who appeared no older than 10 had killed at least 20 people in a northern Nigeria market.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Seizing Assets in Crimea, From Shipyard to Film Studio
item.description: The prime minister and other officials have said the seized property is being nationalized because it was originally acquired illegally.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: At the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in the port of Sevastopol, schoolchildren in uniform took their positions standing guard one morning in November.

item.title: North Korea Offers U.S. Deal to Halt Nuclear Test
item.description: North Korea said that it had told the United States that it would impose a temporary moratorium on nuclear tests if Washington canceled its joint annual military exercises with South Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Marines participated last March in the annual joint landing exercises in Pohang, South Korea.

item.title: In New Era of Terrorism, Voice From Yemen Echoes
item.description: Anwar al-Awlaki, an American-born imam who joined Al Qaeda but was killed by a C.I.A. drone strike in 2011, has remained a leading influence in today’s world of armed jihad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE
item.media:description: The radical cleric Anwar al-Awlaki, shown in a video lecture, has proved to be a sinister and durable inspiration after his death in a C.I.A. drone strike in September 2011.

item.title: News Analysis: Is the War Crimes Court Still Relevant?
item.description: The Palestinian situation is only the latest challenge.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Robin van Lonkhuijsen
item.media:description: Fatou Bensouda, chief prosecutor for the International Criminal Court, faces new challenges.

item.title: Opinion: The Backlash Against African Women
item.description: They are powerful in government, but harassed on the street.
item.dc:creator: By SISONKE MSIMANG

item.title: After Terrorist Attacks, Many French Muslims Wonder: What Now?
item.description: France’s Muslim population — the largest in Europe — seems braced for a potential backlash, both political and personal, after the terrorist attacks.
item.dc:creator: By LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: French Premier Declares ‘War’ on Radical Islam as Paris Girds for Rally
item.description: Law enforcement officials appealed to the public to help find Hayat Boumeddiene, the girlfriend of Amedy Coulibaly, who took hostages at a kosher supermarket.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY and MAÏA de la BAUME

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How to Stop Currency Manipulation
item.description: Restrict it through the Trans-Pacific Partnership.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By JARED BERNSTEIN
